reviews.author: aaronic92351
reviews.title: Self-learning Course with "Wonderful" Grading Scheme
reviews.comment_content:
First Intermediate Accounting Course, covers 10 chapters, mainly on Asset side:
Chapter 1: Financial Reporting and Accounting Standards
Chapter 2: Conceptual Framework for Financial Reporting
Chapter 4: Income Statement and Related Information
Chapter 5: Statement of Financial Position and Statement of Cash Flows
Chapter 7: Cash and Receivables
Chapter 8: Valuation of Inventories: A Cost-Basis Approach
Chapter 9: Inventories: Additional Valuation Issues
Chapter 10: Acquisition and Disposition of PPE
Chapter 11: Depreciation, Impairments, and Fair Value Option for PPE
Chapter 12: Intangible Assets

More in-depth version of ACCT2010 with more journal entries and accounting treatments for different contexts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Blended-learning is adopted, where videos are pre-recorded and uploaded. What you need to do is to watch the assigned videos before going to F2F class (once per week).
However, what she did during F2F class was simply read out the questions from students and explain once again the contents covered in the videos.
The teaching was not effective as she just kept on talking for 90 mins and asked us to write our questions and submit to her at the end of the class. Fewer and fewer people attended the class along the semester.

I still do not understand why blended-learning approach is suitable for an accounting course. I'd prefer her teaching F2F in the classroom than learning all the contents by myself by watching 10-15 videos every week...
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation: 10%
She just said "good questions" will be counted towards participation, but you never know whether you asked a good question...

Graded HWs (Best 10 out of 12): 50%
I got full marks for this component.
(There was mistakes in one of the HWs as well...)

Final Exam: 40%
- Covered all the contents taught
- Lots of journal entries to memorize
- 4 pages of A4 hand-written cheatsheet allowed
- Similar to HWs and After-Chapter Exercises

Final Grade: A+
Although I got an A+, I still cannot agree with the grading scheme.
Most students got full marks for HWs, so basically the Final Exam determines your grade... ngl it was very stressful...
She also mentioned that the exam will consists of MCQs, Fill in the blanks, Calculations and Journal Entries. Yet I wonder where did MCQs and Fill in the blanks go?
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is normal during the semester, just watch the videos in 2x speed and finish the HW for the week.

However, the workload is huge during exam period.
If you aim high, make sure to reserve enough time to review all the materials and finish the recommended practice questions!!
I personally spent 2 weeks to review and do practice questions (one chapter per day), hard works did paid off tho.

reviews.author: dailo
reviews.comment_content:
Can refer to previous reviews for more details on the chapters included.

I would say not too difficult to grasp the concepts and you don't really need to spend too much time understanding everything in detail, just make sure to work on the questions in the textbook so that you can work on the questions quickly in the final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Blended learning was adopted, so you watch the videos each week yourself and ask her if you have any questions through email. The videos are ridiculously long and she talks a lot of irrelevant stuff, so after a while I just gave up on watching the videos and read the slides by myself, I found this to be more effective.

Honestly, it's surprising that an accounting course is adopting the blended learning policy, but it is what it is. Just self-study and do the questions in the textbook before the final as it's very similar to the actual questions in the final.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation: 10%
No idea how its calculated, she just said people who ask her questions through email or in class will get participation points. I never asked any questions. Since it was Zoom this semester, I think attendance was counted through Zoom. Just log into Zoom and do whatever you want, that's what I did.
Homework: 50%
Best 10 out of 12 counted, everyone should get full marks since answers can easily be found online
Final Exam: 40%
Pretty straightforward exam, she said questions will be similar to those in the textbook and she was right. Nothing too challenging and practicing with the questions in the textbook should help secure a decent grade.

Although I got A eventually, I would say the grading is pretty trash because it solely depends on your final and there is no transparency with the grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
One homework every week which is quite easy and can be completed quickly.
No midterm, only final exam, so workload is not a lot

If you studied ACCT before you dont have to panic.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The course was delivered in blended learning mode, you have to watch all videos of the specific chapter every week by yourself, and attend a lecture with Amy once a week. While Amy was pregnant this semester so we had a zoom class every week. You may send her some questions before class and she will mention them in class with all of us. It is helpful if you have questions to ask.
Amy always shares different articles and essays. You may find it interesting if you love accounting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation 10%
Just attend the class and you can get it.

Graded homework 5%*10
There will be 12 homework, and only the best 10 out of 12 will be used.

Final exam 40%
One two-sided A4 cheatsheet is allowed. While you have to put everything in the 12 chapters inside. It is pretty hard since there are a lot of terms and formatting that you have to know. There will be around 13 questions in the exam, and all of them require the preparation of some statements. The exam lasts for 3 hours and I barely completed it. The exam result and statistics are not released.

As a student who only got a B in ACCT2010 and had no accounting background before, I get an A. So I believe the grading is pretty good.
reviews.comment_workload: It is pretty terrible. First, you have to spend around 2-3 hours watching the videos by yourself (which I strongly recommend you double the speed, Amy speaks kinda slow). After that, you have to do homework EVERY WEEK. It takes me a lot of time since I don't have an accounting background. I spent like 2-3 hours per homework.

reviews.author: cyan42
reviews.title: Self learning is important , do more exercises to familiar yourself with the formulas.
reviews.comment_content:
Required textbook : Kieso, Donald E., Weygandt, Jerry J. AND Warfield, Terry D., “Intermediate Accounting: IFRS Edition, 4th Edition”, Wiley.
The textbook is also required for ACCT3020 so make sure you bought the latest version.

Chapter 1 – 2 : background of Accounting and Reporting Standards, full of texts ,not much being tested in the final exam, but they are the basis of later chapters.

Chapter 4 – 5 : Financial statements ( 4 of them, Income Statements, Statement of Financial Position, Statement of Cash Flows, and Statement of changes in equity )
Be careful about the presentation and format of these statements, about 2 -3 questions in the final exam are related to financial statements.

Chapter 6 is skipped, FINA2303 stuff  (time value of money) , present value, future value, and annuity formulas. They are essential for later chapters in calculations.

Chapter 7 : Receivables , Accounts receivables and Notes receivables , calculations of present value and interest of Notes , Secured Borrowing and Refund Liability.

Chapter 8 – 9 : Inventories , valuation issues of inventories

Chapter 10 – 11 : Valuation of PPE and depreciation calculation

Chapter 12 : Intangible assets  and impairment loss of goodwill  ( self-study part for final exam )
reviews.comment_teaching:
The class is blended learning mode , that’s mean lecture + online lecture videos
Professor is pregnant so lectures are conducted online.
Lecture videos are mainly the “teaching part” .

Zoom lecture is Q&A session, Amy will answer to students’ questions about the content taught
(Questions are sent by email , which I believe is counted towards the total grade )
reviews.comment_grading:
10 % Class participation ( counted by asking questions during lecture and by emails )

50 % Online Homework ( easy , most of them are similar to textbook exercises )

40 % Final exam
Final exam include 10 – 15 long questions , covering each chapter taught.

Since online homework is very easy, so in order to have a better grade , make sure you did textbook exercises , they are similar questions to final exam.

No Midterm exam for this course so more time is needed to study for final exam.

My grade : A+ ( study hard for final exam so that you can get a good grade )
reviews.comment_workload:
Each week online homework is released on Sunday, have one week to finish it. Each question has 2 attempts, therefore most people got 50/50 on Online Homework.

Again , Final exam is important cuz it's the only way to differentiate the grade.

reviews.comment_teaching: Professor has prepared many videos for each chapter, you can follow well with the videos. Then there is 1 zoom lecture every week which became Q&A session. In order to let students relate the learning materials with the reality in business world, Professor Zang provided related news to each chapter. She is kind and friendly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 10%
Graded Homework 50%
Final Exam 40%

Class Participation: You are encouraged to raise questions to the instructor, both during and outside the class, and to participate actively in the classroom (Zoom sessions for students not in HK). Some random cold calling would be used to check class participation. Class participation grade is determined by your attendance,  the quality of your answers to questions raised during face-to-face class, and your contribution to class discussions.

ps: I have never raised any question to the Professor, so I guess I score 0 out of 10 in the participation. :(
There are many students keep sending emails just for earning participation, from what I saw, as Professor changed the Zoom session for just answering and explaining the students' questions she received, and could never finish them within 1 hour 20 minutes (except the first lecture and last lecture?)

Homework: all students get Incredible results
Everyone 50/50

So the grade mainly based on the Final (closed book with cheat sheet)
No score released. The questions are not difficult, but I still felt I was PKed as I only studied for around 2 days.

My final grade: A (very out of my expectation)
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week 1 homework, total 12, but only the highest 10 will be counted.
It takes some time to watch all the videos. There are 10-20 videos for each chapter. Some are as short as three minutes; most of them are less than 15 minutes; some longer ones are around 30-50 minutes. For the homework questions, you can find similar ones in the book excercises and the e-book practice questions, so it is not difficult to score in full mark, just time-consuming (can be 1-2 hours or 3-5 hours)

Final: as I have other exams clashed with my finals, I just use 2 days to finish the cheat sheet (one A4 size handwritten note, can write on both sides).

reviews.author: lmfaoooo
reviews.comment_content: The advanced version of ACCT2010, the concepts are much detailed and complicated, 10 chapters in total
reviews.comment_teaching: She adopts a blended learning mode which students only have to attend one specified class per week (can be skipped too!!). For the F2F class, it is somehow a Q&A session that she will explain some difficult concepts or questions that students asked during class or before class through email. For the other class, she will upload the contents and videos on canvas which will be taught that week. She expects every student to watch them before attending the F2F class. For me, I did not watch any of them lmfao because they are ridiculously long. It may take you 3 hours to finish the whole lecture video. Therefore, I read the textbook instead because the things she taught is actually from the textbook. If you want to learn something or at least know what she is talking about during the F2F class, then you really need to spend time to read the textbook or watch the videos before class. Otherwise, you will be just sitting for the whole class doing nothing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 50%
Final Exam: 40%
Participation: 10%

There are 12 online homeworks in total (1 per week) and only the best 10 will be counted. I think students usually get full marks here because there are two attempts for each question. If you do it wrong for the first attempt, then find a friend to ask for their answers. However, the numbers for some questions maybe different as they are auto-generated. Just ask them for the formula is fine.

The final exam covers all the materials taught throughout the semester, and most of the questions are in the form of preparation of journal entries. I think it is the best to study hard for the final exam as it is the key factor that mainly affects your grade.

Not too sure how the participation score is counted. Sometimes, she will give out a piece of blank paper before the F2F class starts and requires students to write their questions on the paper. But seems that attendance will not be taken cuz my friend still got A- even though he skipped all the classes lol.

Lmao I somehow managed to get B+ given the fact that I did not watch any of her lecture videos and by just reading the textbook.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. Just one online homework per week.

reviews.author: Kody
reviews.title: Need a lot of Hard Work
reviews.comment_content:
Content was very standard. The first few classes was about the IFRS framework (which was a bit boring), and then we start talking about the asset side of the B/S (which is the focus of the whole course). Content was not difficult to digest, but we needed to memorize a lot of journal entries, so practice practice practice to understand what situation to do which entry.
There's also a project that focuses on revenue recognition to deepen our understanding of the topic, coz there was a new guideline (IFRS 15) that was just published.
reviews.comment_teaching: Amy was a very good professor, but a lot of the time she reads the PPT, and uses examples from the textbook directly. She has a deep understanding of the market, and will sometimes share her thoughts on some market news during class. But since the examples were really limited, we have to do a lot of practice to understand more. Also, this semester was the first time Amy asked students to do a project for this course, so she didn't really give clear instructions on how to complete the project. In the end, after the presentation, she commented that we should focus a bit more on the quantitative side of things (meaning we should focus on how to do journal entries instead of just explaining the new revenue recognition rules) and the market's reaction to the new rule. So next year be aware of that.
reviews.comment_grading: Standard SBM grading, 25% A. But accounting major students are all very diligent, so it may be hard to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this course is higher than last year, since we have a new online homework platform and a project besides the exams. Always check Canvas for new homework postings to avoid missing deadlines. Before the exam, practice with textbook questions (ideally, finish all of them) as you will definitely come across them during the exams. This year's final exam questions were all from the textbook exercises. Exams are all non-cumulative.
After the midterm, start doing the project, instead of leaving it for the final few weeks, or you won't have much time.
